Reading Comprehension Review



Inspired Leadership
In the summer of 1963, 250,000 people showed up in Washington, D.C., to hear Martin Luther King Jr. speak. No emails were sent out, and there was no website to check the date. And yet thousands of people went. “How do you do that?” asks Simon Sinek.
FOCUS ON BELIEFS
Sinek, an author and consultant who studies leadership, has a theory about why some leaders are able to inspire others to action. He thinks that great leaders, above all, focus on what they believe. They answer questions like “What’s my purpose? Why does my organization exist? Why do I get out of bed in the morning?” For example, Martin Luther King Jr. stood out as a great leader because he told people what he  believed—“I have a dream,” he said, not, “I have a plan.” Many people shared his belief that change was possible, and they decided to join him.
If you talk about what you believe, says Sinek, you will attract those who share the same beliefs. Most of us are followers, but that does not mean we are unthinking1 or easily led. Sinek suggests that we don’t follow leaders because we have to, but because we want to. To illustrate this, he points out that thousands of people didn’t turn up for King himself, but for what he—and they—believed in. “It’s what they  believed about America,” says Sinek, “that got them to travel in a bus for eight hours to stand in the sun in the middle of August.”
Organizations, says Sinek, can also inspire followers by focusing on beliefs. The most successful  businesses do more than just describe the features and benefits of their products. Apple, for instance, communicates its belief in thinking differently and challenging the way things are normally done. This helps to explain, says Sinek, why people stood in line for six hours when the first iPhone came out. They did  this not only because of the technology, but because they wanted to be part of a company they believed in.  In other words, says Sinek, “people don’t buy what you do, they buy why you do it.”
NOT ALL LEADERS INSPIRE
So we make our choices based on why companies and individuals do what they do. Unless we feel a real connection to the leaders in our lives—and share in their beliefs—we won’t follow them. In the end, everyone wants to be part of something they believe in. “Because there are leaders and then there are those who lead,” says Sinek. “Leaders hold a position of power or authority, but those who lead inspire us [ . . . ] We follow those who lead, not for them but for ourselves.”
1 unthinking: adj. acting or speaking without thinking first

items.q: Simon Sinek claims that inspiring leaders focus on their beliefs.
Martin Luther King Jr. used social media (e.g., Facebook) to gather people together.
People came to hear Martin Luther King Jr. speak mostly because they cared about Martin Luther King Jr.
Apple is an example of a successful organization that focuses on its beliefs.
The author of the passage believes the word leaders means the same thing as “those who lead.”

sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Extension


The Fast to Slow Food Movement
Fast food is a global phenomenon.  In major cities across the world, fast food restaurants like the iconic McDonald’s stand out in downtown areas.  This has been a big problem for Italian Carlo Petrini.  When he learned of a McDonald’s restaurant being built in a historic district of Rome in the 1980s, he protested.  Others joined his campaign, and they began what is now known as the slow food movement.
About forty years earlier, the fast food movement was just beginning.  McDonald’s founders and brothers Richard and Maurice McDonald developed an extremely efficient restaurant.  Their kitchen was set up like a factory production line, and their menu featured only a handful of items: burgers, french fries, drinks, and apple pie.  They sold cheap, fast, and tasty food.  Their business took off, many more restaurants were built, and by the 1970s, McDonald’s restaurants were making over a billion dollars in sales. 
The fast food movement became very profitable for companies like McDonald’s because people were attracted to the convenience of fast food.  Their lives had become busier, and they had less time for food preparation.  Fast food seemed like a good solution. 
Carlo Petrini argues that fast food is not a good solution.  Not only is it less healthy, but it negatively affects culture—in the way people prepare and enjoy food.  The slow food movement focuses on making people aware of these issues.  Their purpose is to encourage people to buy organic food from local farms.  They focus on ethical buying; in other words, making sure the prices of the food are fair to both seller and buyer.  Petrini believes that “slow food” is better for the stomach as well as for the community.

items.q: What is the purpose of this passage?
options: to persuade the reader to eat fast food
to compare methods of food preparation
to give the history of two food movements

items.q: Which event happened first?
options: McDonald’s began making over a billion dollars in sales.
Carlo Petrini protested McDonald’s opening in Rome.

items.q: What is NOT an example of how McDonald’s restaurants were efficient?
options: how their kitchen was set up
how many items were on the menu

items.q: Which of the following is NOT mentioned by Carlo Petrini as a disadvantage of fast food?
options: It affects culture in a negative way.

items.q: Why were people attracted to fast food?
What is paragraph 4 mainly about?
options: how local farms raise organic produce
the purpose of the slow food movement

items.q: What is another word for ethical in paragraph 4?
Which word is NOT used in relation to the slow food movement?
Which paragraph is mainly about why people began eating fast food?

sections.passage:
Reading Skills

Qualities of a Good Leader
A good leader has the following three qualities:
• Communicates clearly
A good leader uses words carefully.  He doesn’t say too much or too little.  He understands who his audience is, and he changes the words he uses depending on the person he’s talking to.  He listens well to other people to make sure they understand him and to make sure his decisions and actions meet their needs.
• Values people
A good leader understands that her greatest strengths are the people who follow her.  Without these people, she could accomplish nothing.  She speaks with people respectfully and listens to their concerns.  She makes sure her followers have the resources they need.
• Knows what needs to happen
A great leader thinks about what steps need to be taken and how they will be taken.  This leader is prepared for the future and has a plan for the many possible situations.  She has many goals and knows what she wants.

TED Talk Comprehension


Derek Sivers—How to Start a Movement
Paragraph A
So, ladies and gentlemen, at TED we talk a lot about leadership and how to make a movement. So let’s watch a movement happen, start to finish, in under three minutes and dissect some lessons from it.

Paragraph B
First, of course you know, a leader needs the guts to stand out and be ridiculed. But what he’s doing is so easy to follow. So here’s his first follower with a crucial role; he’s going to show everyone else how to follow.

Paragraph C
Now, notice that the leader embraces him as an equal. So, now it’s not about the leader anymore; it’s about them, plural. Now, there he is calling to his friends. Now, if you notice that the first follower is actually an underestimated form of leadership in itself. It takes guts to stand out like that. The first follower is what transforms a lone nut into a leader.

Paragraph D
And here comes a second follower. Now it’s not a lone nut, it’s not two nuts—three is a crowd, and a crowd is news. So a movement must be public. It’s important to show not just the leader, but the followers, because you find that new followers emulate the followers, not the leader.
a.
Paragraph A
b.
Paragraph B
c.
Paragraph C
d.
Paragraph D

items.q: the purpose of the talk
how a leader takes the first risk
the number of people needed to make a movement
how the first follower is really a leader

sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Read the following excerpt from Derek Sivers’ TED Talk and answer the questions.
sections.passage:
Derek Sivers—How to Start a Movement
So, ladies and gentlemen, at TED we talk a lot about leadership and how to make a movement. So let’s watch a movement happen, start to finish, in under three minutes and dissect some lessons from it.
First, of course you know, a leader needs the guts to stand out and be ridiculed. But what he’s doing is so easy to follow. So here’s his first follower with a crucial role; he’s going to show everyone else how to follow.
Now, notice that the leader embraces him as an equal. So, now it’s not about the leader anymore; it’s about them, plural. Now, there he is calling to his friends. Now, if you notice that the first follower is actually an underestimated form of leadership in itself. It takes guts to stand out like that. The first follower is what transforms a lone nut into a leader.
And here comes a second follower. Now it’s not a lone nut, it’s not two nuts—three is a crowd, and a crowd is news. So a movement must be public. It’s important to show not just the leader, but the followers, because you find that new followers emulate the followers, not the leader.

items.q: What is true about the leader?
options: He is willing to do something even though other people may laugh at him.
He is doing something difficult for others to follow.
He is a movement all by himself.

items.q: What is NOT true of the first follower?
options: He is equal to the leader.
He has the courage to follow.
He makes the leader a follower.

items.q: According to the article, how many people make a crowd?
Who do new followers emulate , or copy?
